data.title: Conflict: a Distributed Condition: Contemporary War Ecologies
data.desc:
Conflict is not an exception or an isolated event — it is a constant condition running through society. It is not limited to war or explicit clashes: it emerges within collective life as friction, as a continuous confrontation between competing needs, systems, and visions.
It is not a punctual episode but a latent and distributed condition. It takes on asymmetric, often invisible forms, embedded in cultural practices, social relations, and infrastructures. Its logic is not confined to violence: it also structures coexistence, shaping who holds privilege and who is pushed to the margins.
Exploring distributed conflicts means reading the present as a field where techniques of offense multiply and blur into the infrastructures society depends on. The goal is to generate critical devices, scenarios, and questions that probe the ambiguous nature of conflict as a diffuse condition in a post-territorial age.

data.title: Analysis of the meaning of words
data.desc:
The term conflict, from Latin confligere (“to clash”), refers to a contrast between forces, interests, or values: it can be social and political (between states, ideologies, groups), cultural and symbolic (between narratives and languages), or psychological (inner tension). It is not only physical confrontation but also a struggle over how reality is interpreted. 
Mediatic, from “media” (means of communication), points to what is spread and amplified through press, TV, radio, social networks, and digital platforms: information is always filtered by formats, interests, and algorithms. 
Mediatic conflict thus means a clash occurring through media (propaganda, narrative wars, manipulation) or one fueled by them, amplifying existing tensions

data.title: How information is transmitted
data.desc:
1) Traditional Media (Broadcasting): press offers slower but deeper coverage, historically setting the agenda; radio is immediate and oral; television dominates with powerful visuals and one-to-many reach, still key in crises.

2) Digital Media: news websites provide continuous updates; social media spread rapid, fragmented, algorithm-filtered content; blogs and forums host opinion exchange; podcasts mix depth and storytelling.

3) Interactive & Instant Media: messaging apps enable fast, private sharing but fuel rumors; live streaming allows real-time participation; citizen journalism turns anyone with a smartphone into a reporter.

4) Emerging Media: generative AI automates news, creates chatbots and deepfakes; AR/VR enable immersive reporting; decentralized platforms offer alternative, non-centralized models.

data.title: Common features
data.desc: All media use a code, whether verbal, visual, or sound; they follow a specific rhythm, such as daily for newspapers, 24/7 for television, and instant for social media; they differ in the level of participation, with traditional media involving a passive audience, while digital media engage an active one that shares, comments, and produces content.

data.title: Possible points of conflict for the major media in general
Conflict node
data.desc:
A conflict node is a critical point within a process, narrative, or social dynamic where different interests, values, or objectives collide. It marks the moment when tensions become visible and opposing forces come into direct confrontation, often requiring dialogue, negotiation, or resolution. 
In media and communication studies, conflict nodes appear when contrasting narratives, interests, or perspectives intersect in news coverage, online debates, or social media interactions. They play a key role in shaping public discourse, as they expose underlying tensions, capture collective attention, trigger participation, and can ultimately drive cultural or social change.

data.title: Filter Bubbles
data.desc:
Personalized information ecosystems created by algorithms that show users only content reflecting their own beliefs.
- They polarize people because you mostly see those who agree with you and increasingly extreme content. 
- You never gain a complete view of reality, but only a portion shaped by your preconceptions, leading to an illusion of control.

data.title: Slacktivism
data.desc:
A critical term describing forms of “low-effort” activism, mostly typical of online contexts.
Those who engage in symbolic gestures may feel “absolved” and fail to move on to more effective forms of activism.

data.title: Washing
data.desc:
Term that describes the strategy by which companies, institutions, or brands appropriate social symbols and causes to “clean up” their image without real commitment (e.g., rainbow-washing, green-washing, pink-washing).
Companies have no interest in actually resolving the conflict; their goal is solely to improve their image for advertising purposes.

data.title: Inconclusive activism
data.desc: Forms of activism that signal support or raise awareness without producing meaningful or lasting change, often limited to symbolic actions

data.title: Dead Internet Theory
data.desc:
The Internet is supposed to be a dynamic, open space populated by real users engaging in genuine interactions.
The problem arises from bots, spam, AI, and fake accounts. Social interactions can become artificial, making it difficult to distinguish between human and non-human activity.

data.title: Automation
data.desc: The use of algorithms, bots, or AI to generate, distribute, or amplify content, which can artificially shape online interactions and public perception.

data.title: Spectacularization (Infotainment)
data.desc:
Information and entertainment are mixed, favoring the sensational aspect of content over depth or informational completeness.
Ordinary or complex events are presented in a sensationalized way, with fear, anger, surprise, and curiosity driving the narrative.

data.title: Click Baiting
data.desc:
Creating sensationalistic titles, images, or previews to attract attention and entice users to click on content.
The content often does not match the headline, which undermines public discourse

data.title: False Balance
data.desc:
A topic is presented as if there are two equally legitimate or valid positions, even when one is scientifically or factually stronger.
It risks creating a distorted perception of reality, making widely accepted issues (e.g., climate change, vaccines) seem controversial and sparking unnecessary debates.

data.title: Mediatic void
data.desc: Mediatic void is a phenomenon in which certain events, issues, or perspectives receive little to no coverage in the media, creating gaps in public awareness. By failing to report on these topics, media outlets can unintentionally or deliberately shape what audiences perceive as important, leaving some problems invisible. This lack of coverage can influence public opinion, political priorities, and social discourse, reinforcing inequalities in attention and limiting informed decision-making among citizens.

data.title: Cherry picking
data.desc: Cherry picking is a media phenomenon in which information is selectively presented to support a particular narrative or argument while ignoring data that might contradict it. By highlighting specific facts, quotes, or statistics and omitting context, media outlets can shape public perception and reinforce biases. This practice distorts reality, misleads audiences, and can polarize opinions, often giving an impression of evidence or consensus that does not accurately reflect the full scope of a situation.

data.title: Media overshadowing
data.desc: Media overshadowing is the phenomenon in which an event or a piece of news receives disproportionate coverage, pushing other relevant issues into the background and causing them to disappear from the media agenda as soon as a more “sensational” story emerges. This mechanism can influence public perception of priorities and is sometimes exploited by governments or political actors to divert attention from uncomfortable issues.

data.title: Fake news
data.desc: Fake news are deliberately false or manipulated stories, spread with the aim of deceiving, influencing public opinion, or gaining political and economic advantages. They spread rapidly, especially online, exploiting social media and the logic of virality, confusing citizens and undermining trust in traditional sources of information. The main effects concern the distortion of public debate, the polarization of opinions, and the creation of false perceptions about real facts and issues, with direct consequences on democratic processes and collective decision-making.

data.title: Deviancy amplification
data.desc: Deviancy amplification is a sociological process in which the media, by excessively emphasizing deviant behavior, end up amplifying its perception and diffusion. The sensationalistic representation of certain episodes can in fact lead public opinion to consider them more frequent or dangerous than they actually are, pushing institutions toward disproportionate repressive responses. This mechanism can fuel stereotypes, reinforce the stigmatization of social groups, and generate a spiral in which deviant phenomena appear amplified, while often remaining marginal in reality.

data.title: Framing
data.desc: Framing is a mass media phenomenon in which the way information is presented shapes how audiences interpret and evaluate events. By selecting certain aspects of a story and emphasizing specific angles, media outlets guide attention toward particular interpretations while downplaying alternative perspectives. This subtle process influences how issues are understood, defining what is seen as a problem, who is considered responsible, and which solutions appear most legitimate. As a result, framing not only organizes public discourse but can also steer political debate and decision-making, often without audiences realizing the extent of its impact.

data.title: Censorship
data.desc: Censorship is the practice of suppressing or controlling information, ideas, or artistic expressions deemed objectionable, sensitive, or dangerous by governments, institutions, or media outlets. By limiting access to certain content, censorship shapes public knowledge and perception, often influencing social, political, and cultural discourse. It can prevent critical debate, obscure truths, and restrict the diversity of voices in society, sometimes being justified as a means of protecting morality, security, or social order, but frequently serving the interests of those in power.

data.title: Manipulation
data.desc: The way content is framed or structured to influence perception, often emphasizing certain aspects while omitting or distorting others to guide audience interpretation.

data.title: Rumor Cascade
data.desc:
A phenomenon in communication and social media where a rumor, news item, or gossip spreads rapidly among people.
Sources are often not verified, generating a chain reaction of unjustified anger or hostility. 
This “telephone game” effect also illustrates how information can change as it circulates through media.

data.title: Cognitive Laziness
data.desc:
Users prefer to remain misinformed rather than engage in fact-checking due to the cognitive effort required.
The tension between digital immediacy and the time needed for verification leads people to accept information as true without checking.

data.title: Immediacy
data.desc:
The world increasingly rewards content and news that are transmitted as quickly as possible; being first is seen as essential.
This speed comes at a cost: the fastest news is often not the most accurate.

data.title: Immediacy / Easy and Fast Information
data.desc: The prioritization of speed in news and content delivery, favoring rapid consumption over accuracy or depth.

data.title: Shitstorm
data.desc:
A massive, rapid, and highly negative public reaction toward a person, company, institution, or online content.
Thousands or millions of users comment, share, or criticize simultaneously, with anger, indignation, and frustration dominating the discourse.

data.title: Argument Culture
data.desc:
A social and media tendency to treat public communication as a battlefield.
Ideas are presented in terms of clash, opposition, and winning rather than dialogue or cooperation.

data.title: Cancel Culture
data.desc:
Individuals, groups or institutions are publicly criticized, boycotted, or excluded after expressing opinions or taking actions considered offensive, discriminatory, or morally unacceptable.
Rather than fostering dialogue, it tends to silence people and reinforce “us versus them” divisions.

data.title: Rage Baiting
data.desc:
Attempting to provoke anger in people through “bait” comments or posts, exploiting the tendency of individuals to take pleasure in creating conflict.
It generates anger and hatred purely for the amusement of a single individual.

data.title: Anger / Public Reaction
data.desc: The emotional responses, especially outrage or frustration, that audiences experience and express in response to provocative or sensational content.

data.title: The media as a stage for anger: we are aggressors, victims, and paying audiences
data.desc: On social networks, and in the media in general, we increasingly witness communicative dynamics that are far more conflictual and hate-driven than in real life. Phenomena such as cyberbullying, shitstorms, cancel culture, argument culture, and rage baiting are clear symptoms. In this context, we find ourselves sometimes as aggressors, sometimes as victims, but above all as the audience that fuels and finances the system. In fact, we actively seek and demand such content: the more a message provokes outrage, the more it is shared, boosting engagement and, in turn, the profits of platforms and news outlets that spread it.

data.title: References
data.desc:
- The Argument Culture (1998), Deborah Tannen 
- Lord of the Flies, William Golding
- How social learning amplifies moral outrage expression in online social networks
- The social dilemma, Netflix series
- “Hated in the Nation” Black Mirror S 6 E 3

data.title: Post-truth: cognitive laziness and the search for truth
data.desc:
The rise of new mass media has transformed the very concept of truth, giving rise to a post-truth era: what matters is no longer whether information is verifiable, but whether it feels “true” because it resonates emotionally or aligns with personal beliefs. 
There is no longer a single shared reality, but multiple, often contradictory versions that coexist and compete. This information overload (often superficial, distorted, or misleading) has devalued truth, making it harder to distinguish from falsehood. 
People increasingly rely on cognitive shortcuts, accepting simple or confirming news without verification. The result is a society of “parallel truths,” where objective truth loses significance. Yet truth remains essential: without it, civil coexistence, public debate, and democracy rest on fragile ground.

data.title: References
data.desc:
- The Truman Show 
- HyperNormalization, Adam Curtis (2016)
- La trahison des images (1929), René Magritte
- Postverità, Anna Maria Lorusso 
- Truth Decay, Jennifer Kavanagh and Michael D. Rich
- Vittoriodublinoblog

data.title: The media as generators of monsters: the propaganda of dehumanization
data.desc: Media often play a central role in shaping perceptions of the enemy, transforming real people into "monsters" to hate or fear. In Nazism, propaganda portrayed Jews as a dehumanized threat, fueling antisemitism until it became socially acceptable and functional to violence. Today, similar dynamics appear in hatred toward immigrants, described by media in certain contexts as invaders or security threats, and in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, where Israeli government narratives dehumanize Palestinians, facilitating genocide. In all cases, media filters shape minds by creating false narratives that fuel conflict, pushing people to hate not what others truly are, but what they've been led to believe they are.

data.title: References
data.desc:
- “Se questo è un uomo”, Primo Levi
- “Men against fire” Black Mirror  S 3 E 5
- “Making Monsters: The Uncanny Power of Dehumanization”, David Livingstone Smith
- “Il sonno della ragione genera mostri”, Francisco Goya

data.title: Synthetic interpretations: information is increasingly filtered by machines
data.desc: Online information is no longer a neutral flow between people: every content, from news to personal posts, is filtered, selected or rewritten by machines. Ranking algorithms determine what appears in feeds, chatbots and generative AI produce texts, images and videos instead of us, synthesis systems like Google AI Overview reformulate what we search without letting us explore deeper. The same applies to our daily exchanges: a message corrected by ChatGPT, news written by software and already processed before reaching us, an image built by a model instead of a photographer, an entire YouTube video generated and dubbed by AI. The paradox is that even human-born content passes through algorithmic filters. Every message, opinion, image risks being translated and reformulated by machines, dissolving communication's authenticity. Thus media's original promise – human-to-human communication – empties: our exchanges no longer happen directly, but within simulated space where machines talk to machines and humans remain passive spectators.

data.title: References
data.desc:
- Imperva – Bad Bot Report 2024/2025
- "Be Right Back" Black Mirror  S 2 E 1
- Only bots
- NewsGuard – AI-Generated News Tracking Center
- “Computational Propaganda Project” — Oxford Internet Institute
- “Computational Propaganda Project” — Oxford Internet Institute
- Bots increase exposure to negative and inflammatory content in online social systems

data.title: Artificial Media-tions
data.desc:
Today, media conflict can be seen as a clash between humans and machines: people interact with machine-generated content as much as with human-made ones. This raises a question: how much is a person’s opinion worth compared to that of a machine? 
At the same time, we are increasingly handing over control of the “media path” to algorithms. Instead of human logic—with its editorial, ethical, or cultural criteria—we face a computational logic that reshapes information flows according to metrics of attention and engagement.

data.title: Post-truth
data.desc:
In the post-truth era, reality is no longer shared but fragmented into multiple, often contradictory versions fueled by fake news. 
Accessing accurate information requires extra effort, which we often avoid, falling into cognitive laziness and choosing what confirms our beliefs. This leads to polarization, reinforced by algorithms that trap us in echo chambers. 
In this context, media conflict can be understood as a clash between real truth and the many “truths” claiming to be right, but also as a conflict between truth as a fundamental value and the personal interests of those who distort it.

data.title: Media as the Stage of Conflict
data.desc:
We increasingly witness communicative dynamics in the media that are more conflictual and hate-driven than in real life. 
Anger becomes the dominant emotion, able to capture attention and generate interaction. 
Conflict thus turns into both information and spectacle, played out before an audience that watches, comments, and actively participates. 
Social media amplify this effect, becoming spaces where social norms fade, and people feel free to criticize and attack without facing real consequences.

data.title: Digital perception
data.desc:
- Context:  
On social media platforms, we find a completely different society: a single opinion is enough to create two opposing sides. Dialogue no longer exists, and people immediately turn to attack, driven by visceral hatred. It is as if we were on an island where the rules of human coexistence no longer apply, returning to a kind of tribal state. But is it this place that corrupts us, or something already within us? There are no laws or consequences; we hide behind nicknames and no longer perceive others as real people — we don’t see them, we don’t hear them, they are no longer human to us.
- Issue:  
In the digital context, we observe more aggressive and conflictual behavior. But where does the root of this problem lie? Is it a lack of social rules? A lack of human contact and perception of others? Inner frustration seeking an outlet? Or a lack of digital empathy?
- Definition and cause of the conflict:  
Conflict occurs between two or more online users. In digital spaces, the perception of the other becomes distorted because we are not physically present: there is no face, no voice, no body. As a result, we push our tone further, often becoming aggressive and losing all sense of empathy.

data.title: Spectacularization
data.desc:
- Context: 
In today’s media landscape, conflict is not only reported but staged. Disputes and scandals become emotional narratives that exploit our negativity bias—the brain’s stronger reaction to negative stimuli. Media use this to attract attention, engagement, and profit.
- Issue: 
When conflict becomes spectacle, the logic of audience overtakes that of truth. Those who shout gain visibility, while nuance and complexity are pushed aside. Communication divides rather than informs.
- Definition and cause of the conflict: 
It’s the clash between the human need for constructive dialogue and a media system that turns discussion into polarizing entertainment. The mix of biological bias and the attention economy drives outrage-based content, transforming conflict from a tool for understanding into a consumable product that fuels polarization and emotional dependency.

data.title: Fake News
data.desc:
- Context:  
We live in an information society where news flows constantly, amplified by mass and social media. On one side stand fact-checkers, journalists, and civic organizations working to verify and protect truth. On the other, networks of disinformation—troll farms, propaganda agencies, companies, even governments—fabricate fake news for profit or political influence, turning truth into a fragile competitor against constructed narratives.
- Issue:
The core problem is not truth itself, but the imbalance of power between those who defend it and those who distort it. A few strive to verify facts, while many exploit technology and scale to manipulate information faster and cheaper. What happens when deception becomes more efficient and profitable than honesty?
- Definition and cause of the conflict:  
The conflict lies in the asymmetry between truth production and lie production. 
Causes: speed and automation of fake news, economic and political incentives, and the slow, costly nature of verification. 
Consequences: public distrust, polarization, and blurred boundaries between fact and fiction.

data.title: Algorithm-driven recommendation systems
data.desc:
- Context:
Recommendation systems are algorithms that decide which content, news, videos, or posts appear on our feeds. They operate across social media, streaming platforms, and even search engines, claiming to optimize the user experience by showing what is most relevant. In reality, they act as invisible filters that shape our view of the world, deciding what we see and what remains hidden.
- Issue:
This hidden selection of reality means that parts of the world are constantly obscured because deemed “irrelevant.” These systems not only show us what we already like but also gradually shape our preferences, guiding them toward what generates more engagement and attention.
- Definition and cause of the conflict:
This raises a crucial question: how much of what we know and desire truly comes from personal choice, and how much is silently trained into us by recommendation systems?

data.title: Media process
data.desc:
- Context: 
We are increasingly delegating control of the media communication process to machines. Instead of human logic—based on editorial judgment, ethics, and cultural awareness—we now rely on algorithmic logic, which organizes and filters information according to attention and engagement metrics. What we see or read is no longer the result of human dialogue but of automated systems shaping every step of communication.
- Issue: 
Is it right for algorithms to manage information more than people do? Does the pursuit of speed and responsiveness in mass media justify automation at the expense of human oversight, accuracy, and ethical responsibility?
- Definition and cause of the conflict: 
This is a clash between human editorial control and algorithmic efficiency. Automation promises precision and immediacy, but risks eroding critical judgment, accountability, and the human dimension of communication

data.title: Trial by media
data.desc:
- Context: 
Mass media construct parallel trials alongside judicial ones. They don't merely report facts but amplify them, building narratives that assign guilt or innocence before any court does. This transforms real legal cases into spectacle, shaping public opinion more powerfully than justice itself.
- Issue: 
Should media conduct public trials that compete with institutional justice? Does the right to information justify narratives that violate privacy, presumption of innocence, and due process, often influencing legal proceedings themselves?
- Definition and cause of the conflict: 
This is a clash between legal justice, governed by rules and procedures, and perceived justice, driven by media and public opinion. The judiciary demands autonomy; the public demands speed and transparency. In a scenario where media tribunals replace official courts, this conflict intensifies: no shared rules exist, arbitrariness increases, and boundaries between truth, reputation, and justice dissolve. The root cause lies in institutional distrust and media visibility's growing centrality, raising the question: who truly decides people's fate?

data.title: Trial by media
data.desc:
- Context:  
The media trial has become a structural element of contemporary society — a true parallel arena of judgment that influences individuals, institutions, and justice systems. It is a complex dynamic producing contradictory effects: destructive (damage to reputations and distorted narratives) and emancipatory or amplifying (encouraging denunciations and prompting justice).

- Issue and conflict:  
Although not an official court, the media trial generates real and often irreversible consequences. Public opinion becomes the ultimate judge, capable of acquitting or condemning long before the courtroom does. Is the media trial, therefore, a legitimate phenomenon?
The conflict lies between judicial authority and public opinion: on one side, the judiciary claims its autonomy and adherence to rules; on the other, the public demands quick answers and transparency.

data.title: Data
data.desc:
- The judicial case of Enzo Tortora (1983) is known as the first media trial in Italy. A judicial error turned into a moral condemnation by the press and public opinion even before the courts, leading to the unfounded arrest of a famous TV host.
- The Amanda Knox and Raffaele Sollecito case was marked by intense media attention, superficial investigation, and contaminated evidence, resulting in a long judicial process with convictions later overturned in 2015. Despite their acquittal, part of public opinion continued to view them as guilty.
- The case of Denise Pipitone (Italy, 2004), a missing child, gained enormous media resonance. Journalistic investigations and public pressure repeatedly pushed the judiciary to reopen the case.
- The Harvey Weinstein scandal erupted in 2017, when numerous women — including Hollywood actresses — accused him of sexual harassment and assault. The media trial that followed sparked the #MeToo movement and a global debate on power and abuse in the entertainment industry. Public exposure led to several legal trials and Weinstein’s final conviction for rape in 2023.

data.title: What if
data.desc: What if official courts were abolished in favor of a media tribunal?  In a future reality where legal institutions have collapsed due to a drastic decline in public trust, and where public opinion holds ultimate authority, the people’s judgment becomes the only one that matters. Thus, a new form of justice emerges — the media tribunal — where visibility replaces evidence, and collective sentiment becomes the new law.

data.title: Entity-subject
data.desc: The entity-subject is the institution responsible for the communicative and logistical system of the media tribunal: it operates both as a television format and as an integrated application designed for public debate and collective judgment.

data.title: Fake News
data.desc:
- Context: 
Disinformation has become a true economic industry. Fake news generate traffic and profit; troll farms operate like agencies; influencers monetize viral falsehoods. Social media turn news into emotional, competitive entertainment, rewarding attention over truth. Lies become narrative products, consumed like TV shows or series.
- Issue: 
The problem is no longer separating truth from lies, but that falsehood now has higher cultural and economic valuethan truth. Fact-checkers struggle, while captivating storytellers thrive, eroding media credibility and creating epistemic uncertainty where every narrative competes equally.
- Conflict: 
A clash between public responsibility and 
entertainment logic: the system rewards those who attract and engage—even by distorting reality—while truthful journalism loses visibility and influence

data.title: Data
data.desc:
- The Carter Center – The “Economy of Disinformation”: Disinformation is an economic sector incentivizing false narratives to generate ad revenue. In 2018, fake news sites earned tens of millions of dollars. MIT research shows false content spreads 6x faster on social media. “Fake news wins in speed, and therefore in reputational power.”

- Who Funds Misinformation? – arXiv Study: Analysis of 2,400+ sites shows official ad networks (Google, IndexExchange) work with fake news sites. Owners often have legitimate businesses, making disinformation a branch of a broader profit model. Shows disinformation as a real economic activity, supporting the revenue-driven logic of a FAKE institution.

data.title: What if
data.desc:
What if fake news became a creative industry?

In a future reality where the reputation of truth has completely collapsed and disinformation is no longer seen as a threat, fake news become the norm—valued, appreciated, and judged for their creativity and entertainment power, rather than their accuracy.

data.title: Entity-subject
data.desc: Entity/organization promoting an international institution that celebrates creative disinformation. The mission of this institution is to promote, recognize, and reward the ability to transform facts into engaging stories, regardless of their truthfulness.

data.title: Media Desensitization
data.desc:
- Context:  
We live in a hyperconnected society where wars, disasters, and tragedies reach us in real time through a constant stream of images and videos. While initial exposure provokes shock and empathy, over time it often produces the opposite effect: habituation, emotional numbness, and detachment. Defense mechanisms develop, allowing us to perceive suffering as distant or unreal, making genuine compassion increasingly difficult.
- Issue and conflict:  
Continuous exposure to pain and violence anesthetizes our empathic capacity. We struggle to feel compassion for suffering that does not affect us directly, and we become indifferent to devastating images. Are we truly becoming insensitive, or are we merely trying to protect ourselves in a world overflowing with injustice and tragedy? The conflict lies between the human need for empathy and the psychological need for self-preservation.

data.title: Data
data.desc: A study titled Desensitization to Media Violence Over a Short Period of Time explored how repeated exposure to violent media affects emotional response. Participants who watched violent scenes reported less solidarity with victims and greater enjoyment of violent content over time. Results showed that repeated exposure reduces the psychological impact of violence, creating emotional detachment and normalizing aggression. The more we see, the less we feel.

data.title: What if
data.desc: What if the media could broadcast not only images of suffering, but also the last words of those facing death? In a future society where empathy has faded, a new digital platform emerges: a streaming service transmitting the final voices of victims from around the world. Its goal is to restore emotional connection by confronting audiences with raw humanity—forcing them to feel again.

data.title: Entity-subject
data.desc: The entity-subject is a technological institution developing a digital streaming platform dedicated to archiving and broadcasting real last words of victims of war, disaster, or injustice. It functions as both a memorial and an experiment in emotional reactivation, testing whether empathy can be rekindled through direct auditory experience.

data.title: The attention economy
data.desc:
- Context: 
Attention has become the most contested resource. Media compete constantly to capture it, transforming news and events into rapid, emotional, visually captivating products. Social algorithms reward immediate reactions over complex reflections. Political themes and tragedies are packaged as spectacle—viral clips, sensationalist headlines, striking images. Reality is no longer represented but made consumable in seconds, following show business and attention market logic.
- Issue and conflict: 
What appears publicly must entertain to exist: complexity disappears, replaced by immediate emotions and powerful images. In this attention battle, do we seek form or content? Who wins—those offering substance or those offering spectacle?

data.title: Negativity Bias
data.desc:
- Context:  
In today’s media ecosystem, we are surrounded by an unprecedented flood of information. News outlets, digital platforms, and social media constantly compete for attention in a system driven by speed and excess. Our brains, predisposed to the negativity bias — the tendency to notice and remember negative events more than positive ones — are continuously exposed to stories of conflict, crisis, and catastrophe.  This tendency is reinforced by market logic and algorithms: negative content generates more clicks, interactions, and shares, and is therefore prioritized. Studies show that every additional negative word in a headline increases its click-through rate by about 2.3%, while positive words reduce it. News with negative language is shared nearly twice as often as neutral or positive ones, and those who consume more negative content experience a measurable decline in mood and well-being. Negativity is thus not favored because it is truer, but because it is more “profitable” in terms of attention, creating a growing gap between real complexity and the dark, distorted image of the world we receive.
- Issue and conflict:  
What kind of relationship with reality are we building when information feeds primarily on negativity? The conflict lies between real and perceived reality: the more the media amplify the negative, the more we perceive the world as dangerous and unstable. This leads to emotional numbness and anxiety, producing a paradoxical dependence — the more negative the news, the more we crave it. Media and platforms sustain this cycle, shaping collective sensitivity around fear and distress.

data.title: What if
data.desc: What if, in an overstimulated world, negative news became the only way to feel alive? In such a scenario, fear and anxiety would no longer be side effects but the main source of emotional stimulation. Society would develop an addiction to negativity, seeking distressing content to escape boredom and emotional flatness, reinforcing a distorted perception of reality.

data.title: Entity-subject
data.desc: The entity-subject could be imagined as The Curator of Negativity — an algorithmic platform designed to select, produce, and amplify negative content to satisfy this emotional dependence. Its mission is to maintain collective engagement and ensure a constant emotional charge, turning distress into a resource and negativity into the new norm.

data.title: Data
data.desc: Recent studies confirm this trend: a large-scale analysis found that each additional negative word in a headline increases the click-through rate (CTR) by about 2.3% compared to an average headline, while positive words decrease it (Nature Human Behaviour, 2023). Moreover, news articles with negative language are shared almost twice as often as neutral or positive ones, according to an analysis of 95,282 articles and 579 million social media posts (Scientific Reports, 2024). Finally, there is also a link between the type of content we consume and our emotional state: recent research shows that people who browse more negative content tend to experience a decline in mood and mental well-being, creating a feedback loop between information consumption and psychological state (EurekAlert, 2024).

data.title: What if
data.desc: What if entertainment no longer needed content? In a future where attention spans have collapsed, only captivating form matters. Television broadcasts videos so fast and color-saturated they're almost psychedelic. They contain no information, nothing happens—yet we stay glued like moths to light.

data.title: Entity-subject
data.desc: A museum of obsolete media artifacts, narrated through this new visual language.
